intro: Anguillaria caricina, commonly known as the Florida anguillaria, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Araceae, which includes many aquatic and semi-aquatic plants. The plant is characterized by its arrow-shaped leaves and clusters of small, white flowers that bloom in the summer. It typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds. Anguillaria caricina plays a role in supporting local wildlife, including insects and amphibians.
